intro.title: Your Trusted Immigration Partner
intro.description: Our expert advisors provide personalized assistance for all your immigration needs, ensuring a successful journey toward residency. We work directly with USCIS services, guaranteeing accuracy and efficiency in every application.

serviceItems.title: Citizenship
serviceItems.description: Assistance with Form N-400 for a smooth citizenship process.
serviceItems.content: USCIS Form N-400: Application for U.S. Citizenship
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText: To qualify for U.S. citizenship, you must have been a permanent resident (Green Card holder) for at least 5 years. If you're married to a U.S. citizen, this period is reduced to 3 years. During this time, you must have continuously lived in the United States.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText: You must have been physically present in the U.S. for at least 30 months of the last 5 years before applying. If married to a U.S. citizen, you must have been present for at least 18 months of the last 3 years.
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText: To be eligible, you must demonstrate good moral character. This includes paying taxes, obeying U.S. laws, and not having serious criminal records. USCIS will evaluate your conduct during the required residency period.
serviceItems.contentFourPointText: One of the final steps to obtain citizenship is taking the Oath of Allegiance to the United States. By doing so, you pledge to support and defend the Constitution and laws of the country, renouncing allegiance to other nations.
serviceItems.contentFinal: If you meet these basic requirements, you can proceed to complete and submit Form N-400 to begin your journey toward U.S. citizenship. Good luck!

serviceItems.title: Employment Authorization
serviceItems.description: Expert guidance on Form I-765 to obtain your Employment Authorization Document.
serviceItems.content: Everything You Need to Know About the EAD
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Employment Authorization Document that allows you to work legally in the United States
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText: The Employment Authorization Document (EAD) is a work permit issued by USCIS that demonstrates your legal right to work in the U.S. It is obtained through Form I-765 and contains: your name, photo, A-number, immigration category, and validity dates.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
Non-citizens and non-permanent residents who need to work legally, including:
- Asylum seekers/refugees
- Students (certain types of employment)
- Adjustment of status applicants
- TPS beneficiaries
- Visa holders' spouses (K, J-2, E, L)
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
1. Initial EAD: First application
2. Renewal: Submit ‚â§120 days before expiration
3. Replacement: For lost/damaged cards

Process: Submit Form I-765 to receive temporary authorization (duration varies by immigration status). Approval allows work for any employer without sponsorship.
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
- Legal work authorization
- No employer restrictions
- Valid for completing Form I-9
- Work flexibility

Note: Processing times vary. Renew early to avoid employment interruptions.
serviceItems.contentFinal: For updated information on requirements and processing times, always check the official USCIS website.

serviceItems.title: Green Card
serviceItems.description: Support with Form I-485 to adjust your status to permanent resident.
serviceItems.content: Adjustment of Status for Permanent Residence
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Green Card application from within the United States
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText:
Form I-485 allows certain foreigners in the U.S. to change their immigration status to permanent resident (obtain Green Card). It must be filed with USCIS and is available to individuals with:
- Approved immigrant petition
- Current priority date
- Valid status in the country
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
1. Be physically present in the U.S.
2. Have an approved immigrant petition (unless asylum/refugee)
3. Visa available (current priority date)
4. No serious immigration violations
5. Be admissible to the U.S.
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
1. Family: Spouses, parents, or children of U.S. citizens
2. Employment: Employer-sponsored
3. Asylum/Refugees: After 1 year in status
4. Special Cases: VAWA, SIV, among others

*Individuals outside the U.S. must follow consular processing
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
Advantages:
- Allows work with EAD while processing
- Possibility to travel with Advance Parole
- Path to citizenship (after 3-5 years)

Process:
1. Submit I-485 + documents
2. Attend biometrics appointment
3. Interview (in most cases)
4. USCIS decision

*Refugees are exempt from fees
serviceItems.contentFinal: For more information on specific requirements and necessary documentation, visit the official USCIS website or consult with a qualified immigration attorney.

serviceItems.title: Visas
serviceItems.description: Help with Form DS-160 for B1/B2 visitor visas for business or tourism.
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Online application for business (B1) or tourism (B2) visas
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText:
The DS-160 is the mandatory electronic form to apply for:

‚Ä¢ Business visas (B1)
‚Ä¢ Tourism visas (B2)
‚Ä¢ Combined B1/B2 visas

It must be completed before scheduling the consular interview.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
Required documentation:

1. Valid passport (6+ months validity)
2. Recent digital photo (5x5 cm, white background)
3. Travel itinerary (flights, accommodation)
4. Proof of economic/social ties in your country
5. For B1: Company letter detailing trip purpose
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
1. **Complete the DS-160** online:
   - Personal data
   - Travel history
   - Employment information
   - U.S. contacts

2. **Pay the MRV fee** ($160 USD)

3. **Schedule interview** at the consulate

4. **Attend the appointment** with all documents
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
To increase your approval chances:

‚Ä¢ Verify all data three times
‚Ä¢ Answers must be consistent with your documentation
‚Ä¢ Prepare for the interview:
  - Clearly explain the trip purpose
  - Demonstrate you'll return to your country
  - Bring original documents and copies

‚Ä¢ Avoid mentioning intent to work or study
serviceItems.contentFinal: Important: The DS-160 does not guarantee visa approval. The final decision is made by the consular officer during the interview. Typical processing: 2-3 weeks.

serviceItems.title: Family Sponsorship
serviceItems.description: Green Card for relatives with Form I-130.
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Help your relative obtain legal permanent residence in the U.S.
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText:
Form I-130 is used by U.S. citizens and permanent residents to:

‚Ä¢ Establish a qualifying family relationship
‚Ä¢ Initiate the family-based immigration process
‚Ä¢ Obtain a visa number for eligible relatives

This is the first step to get a Green Card for your relative.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
U.S. Citizens Can Petition:
- Spouse
- Parents
- Children (any age/marital status)
- Siblings

Permanent Residents Can Petition:
- Spouse
- Unmarried children (any age)

Note: You must file separate I-130 forms for each relative.
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
Essential evidence includes:

1. Proof of your status:
   - Birth certificate (citizens)
   - Naturalization certificate
   - Green Card (permanent residents)

2. Proof of family relationship:
   - Marriage certificates
   - Birth certificates
   - Adoption decrees

3. Financial support evidence (for subsequent Form I-864)
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
1. File Form I-130 with USCIS
2. Wait for petition approval
3. Relative applies for visa:
   - Abroad: Through consular processing
   - In U.S.: Via adjustment of status (Form I-485)

Processing Times:
‚Ä¢ Immediate relatives: No wait
‚Ä¢ Others: Varies by category/country (1-10+ years)

Note: All applicants must pass medical and background checks
serviceItems.contentFinal: Important: I-130 approval doesn't guarantee the visa. Your relative must still meet all eligibility requirements. Consult an immigration attorney for complex cases.

serviceItems.title: DACA Renewal
serviceItems.description: Renew your DACA status with Form I-821D.
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Temporary protection for eligible individuals who arrived in the U.S. as children
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText:
‚Ä¢ Renewals Only: USCIS currently only processes DACA renewal applications
‚Ä¢ No New Applications: Initial applications are not being accepted
‚Ä¢ Limited Window: Only those with status expiring between 9/5/2017 and 3/5/2018 can renew

Note: Those who never had DACA cannot currently apply
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
To qualify for DACA you must:

1. Have entered the U.S. before age 16
2. Be under 31 as of 6/15/2012
3. Have continuously resided in the U.S. since 6/15/2007
4. Be physically present on 6/15/2012
5. Have no legal status on 6/15/2012
6. Meet education/military requirements:
   - Currently in school OR
   - Have high school diploma/GED OR
   - Be an honorably discharged veteran
7. Have no serious criminal history
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
Necessary proofs include:

‚Ä¢ Identity Documents:
  - Passport/birth certificate
  - Government IDs

‚Ä¢ Proof of Continuous Residence:
  - School/medical records
  - Employment history
  - Financial records

‚Ä¢ Education/Military Proof:
  - Diplomas/transcripts
  - GED certificate
  - Military service records
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
For eligible renewals:

1. File Form I-821D
2. Submit Form I-765 for work authorization
3. Pay $495 fee
4. Provide biometrics
5. Wait for USCIS processing

Processing Time: Typically 4-6 months

Benefits:
‚Ä¢ Protection from deportation
‚Ä¢ Work authorization
‚Ä¢ Social Security Number

Note: DACA does NOT provide:
‚Ä¢ Permanent resident status
‚Ä¢ Path to citizenship
‚Ä¢ Federal financial aid eligibility
serviceItems.contentFinal: Important: If your DACA expired after March 2018, immediately consult an immigration attorney. Court rulings may affect program availability - check USCIS website for updates before applying.

serviceItems.title: Asylum Application
serviceItems.description: Assistance with Form I-589 for asylum seekers.
serviceItems.content: Protection Against Persecution in the U.S.
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Immigration process for individuals fearing persecution in their home country
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText:
Form I-589 serves three key purposes:

‚Ä¢ Asylum application (permanent protection)
‚Ä¢ Withholding of removal petition (protection against deportation)
‚Ä¢ Protection under the Convention Against Torture (CAT)

This is the main form to seek protection in the U.S. based on fear of persecution.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
To qualify you must:

1. Demonstrate well-founded fear of persecution due to:
   - Race/Religion
   - Nationality
   - Political opinion
   - Membership in particular social group

2. Be physically present in the U.S. (regardless of entry method)
3. File within 1 year of arrival (with exceptions for extraordinary circumstances)
4. Not have:
   - Previous deportation orders
   - Asylum application denied after full hearing
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
Essential evidence includes:

‚Ä¢ Completed Form I-589
‚Ä¢ Detailed personal statement:
  - Specific persecution incidents
  - Country conditions
  - Why you can't return

‚Ä¢ Supporting evidence:
  - Medical/psychological reports
  - Police reports
  - News articles
  - Witness statements
  - Certified translations of foreign documents

‚Ä¢ Two passport-style photos
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
Steps to Apply:
1. Complete and sign Form I-589
2. Compile supporting evidence
3. Submit to USCIS
4. Attend biometrics appointment
5. Interview with asylum officer
6. Receive decision

Potential Benefits:
‚Ä¢ Protection from deportation
‚Ä¢ Work authorization
‚Ä¢ Path to permanent residence
‚Ä¢ Ability to petition for relatives
‚Ä¢ Access to social services
serviceItems.contentFinal:
Important: Asylum cases are complex. It is strongly recommended to:
‚Ä¢ Consult with an immigration attorney
‚Ä¢ File application within the 1-year deadline
‚Ä¢ Provide detailed and consistent evidence
‚Ä¢ Check USCIS website for current processing times

serviceItems.title: Certificate of Citizenship
serviceItems.description: Establish your status with Form N-600.
serviceItems.content: U.S. Certificate of Citizenship: Form N-600
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: A person born outside the U.S. to U.S. citizen parents may have already acquired citizenship. To document their citizenship status based on ancestry, they can file Form N-600, Application for Certificate of Citizenship.
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText: A person may file Form N-600 if they are claiming U.S. citizenship by law while in the U.S. or if they were born abroad to U.S. citizen parents.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
You automatically become a U.S. citizen if you meet the following requirements:
- Citizen Parent: At least one parent is a citizen by birth or naturalization.
- U.S. Residence: The individual lives in the U.S. with their citizen parent.
- Legal Admission as Permanent Resident: The individual was legally admitted as a permanent resident.
- Under 18: The individual is still under 18 years old.
- Legal Custody: The individual is a biological child under legal custody of citizen parent before turning 16.
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
An individual born outside the U.S. to citizen parents may claim automatic citizenship at birth if they meet:
- Both parents are citizens, and one resided in the U.S. before birth.
- Or, if one parent is foreign and the other is a citizen who, before birth, was physically present in the U.S. for at least 5 years (2 after age 14).
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
A person may also apply if before turning 18 and before 2/27/2001:
- Lived continuously in the U.S. as a legal permanent resident; and
- Both parents, the custodial parent, or the sole surviving parent naturalized as citizens.
serviceItems.contentFivePointText: For adopted or biological children under 18 who meet requirements under INA, the application must be filed by the citizen parent or legal guardian with custody.
serviceItems.contentSixPointText: To begin the process, you must complete and file Form N-600 with the required documentation showing you meet the specified criteria. This certificate serves as official proof of your status as a U.S. citizen.
